writingDetail.html:
Bombs The first thing to do with any sealed pool is the obvious one - It's what everybody does... check your rares and see if you got any bombs!

I don't intend to sit here and tell you that Sealed isn't a rare-dominated format. In 90%+ of cases, your final deck should be one that allows you to play the strongest cards in your pool, most of which will be rares.

Still, there are a few nuances here. When I open a sealed pool, I'm looking for bombs, but those bombs don't have to be individual rare cards. I also consider powerful uncommons that I view as on the level of rares (think cards on the level of Hollow Marauder, which has a case for being better than powerful mythic Hostile Investigator in the right context).

I also might consider a really powerful synergy package as on the level of a bomb when it comes to pulling me into a color. Think about something like 2X Omenport vigilante, 2X Thunder Lasso. Each of these cards is pretty underwhelming on its own, but having this package in a deck allows me to be attacking with a 3/3 double strike that gets blockers out of the way on turn 3 of a good 20% of games. That's an interaction that demands removal. Another example might be a package of 2X Mourner's Surprise, 1X Honest Rutstein, 1X Spinewoods Armadillo. While these are individually strong cards, I don't think any of them are bombs... but the package, when considered as a whole, adds a dramatic amount of both consistency and redundancy to a deck, concepts that we'll cover later.

So what do our "bombs" look like in this pool?

Pretty much nonexistent. Some of these are very high quality cards, but none of them rise to the level of bombs, in my opinion. Stoic Sphinx is the strongest, along with Freestrider Lookout, but none of these cards will take over a game in most situations where they go uncontested. A quick scan of the rest of the pool doesn't turn up any game-warping synergy packages or bomb-level uncommons, so we're looking at a mostly bomb-less pool.

GIVE UP!!! PACK IT IN!!!! POOL SUCKS!!!!!

... calm down. There are more way than one for a pool to be good. We still have a few things to check.

The Mana The second thing I always check in a sealed pool is my mana. In some formats this is pretty much a check for dual lands, but nowadays, most sets also have colorless fixing and often some amount of smoothing/fixing effects, usually in green, but sometimes in other colors also (think Treasure Dredger).

Checking your bombs is how you figure out what you want to play. Checking your mana is how you figure out what you actually can play.

Variance in mana optionality is a HUGELY important part of a sealed pool. If you've got a wide variety of fixing in colors that line up with your bombs, or even better, some strong universal fixers, the world is your oyster. So where are we with this pool?

NOW we're talkin!!!!!!!

This pool is a significant outlier when it comes to the mana. Not only do we have four universal land fixers in the Mirage Mesas, we've also got plenty of dual lands across a wide range of colors, three patient naturalists in green, and some additional playable fixing in a Hardbristle Bandit and our FreeStrider Lookout.

I've pulled in a few other cards that count as pseudo-fixing, although they're not going to be relevant for this pool. Card selection and treasure makers definitely count as fixing in certain contexts - Card draw adds consistency to greedier decks and decks that are splashing late-game cards, and treasure makers add sources for single-card, high-impact splashes.

The main thing I'm thinking at this stage is that this pool is lacking in overall power, but is pretty much unlimited in the ways it can fit the power it does have into the deck - as long as it's base-green. Even a nongreen deck would still have significantly more fixing ability than an average pool, but a green deck in this pool can be a true 5-color pile. So we're basically left with the task of putting together the most powerful 23 cards possible.

Now, "making the mana work" will still factor into our decision making in this pool for sure - but it will be a question of consistency and speed rather than "splashability". It's not about which cards we "can" play, it's about which cards go together most smoothly.

This pool's mana is its' superpower.

Almost every pool has a superpower. Sometimes it's a couple powerful bombs, but players often misbuild and underestimate pools that have a different outlier strength. Usually the best build will try to leverage your pool's greatest strength.
